preface.title: Preface
preface.para: DPS hides directory structure and xi:include structure. Instead, it works on publications: a root document (article, book, part, set, or reference) referred to by its xml:id.
The dls command will show a listing of all publications found in home and its subdirectories.
The dp-pdf, dp-chm, and dp-wh commands transform a publication into PDF, Microsoft CHM source, or Webhelp, respectively. The transformations may be customized by overriding the stock transformations.
dp-pf will list all profiling information for a document; dp-lint will list trademarks and other useful information.
For those times you need to work with directory structures, dwhereis will provide the absolute path to a publication; given a path, dwhichis will identify the root element xml:id.

chapter.title: Installing DPS
chapter.para: The Docbook Publishing System comprises a suite of Java applications. Central to them is XMLSH, a Bash-like shell environment that supports a set of utilities and command-line conventions that make it easy to create XML transformation workflows.

note.para: On OS X and Linux systems, DPS is self-installing: on boot, it can fetch XMLSH and install it to the DPS opt directory.
On Windows systems there is no standard capability for fetching files: after cloning DPS you will need to install XMLSH manually before you can successfully boot DPS. See for details.

chapter.para: There are two installation scenarios. In both cases your Docbook 5 source is in a subdirectory of home and your customizations are in usr.

section.title: Using DPS Standalone
section.para: In this scenario, you clone the DPS repository directly. This provides you with a work directory that uses the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. Consequently, the DPS set of commands are in bin and sbin, its libraries are in lib, and supporting software is in opt.

The DPS repository ignores the home and usr directories. It is strongly recommended that you revise .gitignore and configure a new remote origin (ie. decouple from the DPS Git repository, so that your home and usr directories are tracked):git config remote.origin.url git://your.server.com/project.git Using DPS Standalone
Clone the DPS repository:git clone git@github.com:davidpriest/dps.git MyPubs cd MyPubs
Create your documentation and customization subdirectories:mkdir home/doc-source mkdir usr
???
Profit!

section.title: Using DPS in a Superproject
section.para: In this scenario, you create a superproject that contains aliases to the DPS boot commands and install DPS as a submodule in opt.

step.para: Create your superproject:mkdir MySuperProj cd MySuperProj git init
Add DPS as a submodule:git submodule add git@github.com:davidpriest/dps.git opt/dps/
Install your documentation and customizations as submodules:git submodule add git@github.com:yourname/MyDocs home/doc-source/ git submodule add git@github.com:yourname/MyDocsSupp usr/
Initialize and update the submodules, installing them:git submodule init git submodule update
Push the superproject to your git repository:git config add remote.origin git://your.server.com/project.git

section.title: Publication Structure
section.para: The following Docbook5 root elements are recognized as publications: article, book, part, set, reference.

Publications must have an info element as a child of the root element. The info element must have two filename descendants:
filename[role="filename"]
The output file name for the publication, with no extension. The publication will be placed in home/doc-review or home/doc-release. PDF files will be given the .pdf extension. CHM and Webhelp output will be placed in a directory, with -chm or -webhelp appended to the name.
filename[role="style"]
The suffix for the XSL transformation that will be applied to the publication. The usr/lib/xslt directory will be checked for the presence of an appropriate transformation (fo/style/root-element.xsl, chm/style/root-element.xsl, webhelp/style/root-element.xsl).
Failing to discover a customized transformation, the pipeline will attempt to use the publication's root element to identify the appropriate stock transformation (ie. lib/xslt/fo/article.xsl, lib/xslt/chm/book.xsl).
DPS does not yet have stock transformations for all combinations of root elements and output formats.

section.title: Profiling
section.para:
DPS supports simple profiling through the use of four conditions:
*[condition="nopub"]
Do not publish this element under any condition.
*[condition="draft"]
Publish this element only when publishing a review edition.
*[condition="inc: id"]
Publish this element only if it or an ancestor element has the specified xml:id.
*[condition="exc: id"]
Exclude this element if it or an ancestor element has the specified xml:id.
It also has limited (but improving) support for Docbook XSL profiling features, using audience, os, vendor, etceteras attributes.

section.title: Purple Numbering
section.para: When publishing a review PDF, “purple numbering” and changebars are applied during the transformation process. Purple numbers are formed by combining the repository revision number and element position. Used in debugging, a purple number allows you to recreate the original document and identify the exact paragraph in which an error was made.
Changebars are indicated using the background colour and text styling of the purple number.

section.title: Configuring Purple Numbers
section.para: The DPS repository does not track the home and usr directories, allowing you to use a different CVS for client documentation. In usr/etc/config.properties, set repotype to svn, mercurial, or git appropriately.

section.title: Custom Commands
section.para: DPS provides basic publishing pipelines for PDF, CHM, and Webhelp. Chances are, however, that you will need to create a custom pipeline to accommodate branding, media inclusion, queries, and other complex requirements.

Customization is supported by providing several commands that produce intermediate files; of particular note, the dp-db5 command. This pipeline performs inclusions, xml:id normalization, DPS profiling, and optional purple numbering and changebars. Its return value is a full path to the resulting file.

You can then perform custom transformation and modification of the collated and profiled Docbook file, before passing it into the dp-fo/dp-pdf, dp-chm, or dp-wh commands. Copying the final results from tmp to doc-review or doc-release will be the final step of your custom pipeline.

Here is a simple example that transforms a specific document (my_publication) to PDF, with an intermediate step that allows branding of a product name and a destination file name that differs from the one defined in the publication's root/info/filename[role="filename"] element.

para.programlisting:
BRAND=$1 DRAFT="no" DEBUG="no" P="my_publication" du_setpub
try { IN=$(dp-db5 --tmp $PID) OUT=$T"_16.db5.xml" xed -i $IN -r "$BRAND" -e "//*:phrase[contains(text(),'xBRANDx')]" > $OUT IN=$(dp-fo --tmp $OUT) OUT=$(dp-pdf --tmp $IN) } catch X { echo "" echo "##DPS>>" echo $X echo "<<DPS##" echo "" return 1 } finally { FOUT=$BRAND"_User_Guide.pdf" p:cp -r -f "$OUT" "$USRREL/$FOUT" echo "$USRREL/$FOUT" clean return 0 }

appendix.title: DPS Scripting Commands
appendix.para: A few commands are available for setting up common variables. These commands are found in sbin. Most of them set variables that are used internally by the publishing commands.

listitem.para: An XMLSH script called by the boot process to configure a number of DPS-specific variables and functions.
An XMLSH script called by the boot process to confirm that component parts are available; if parts are missing, an attempt is made to download and install them (generally to opt).
The du_setopt_dp function parses command line options and sets a number of internal variables. This function is used by the dp-db5/-chm/-fo/-pdf/-wh commands.

The du_setpub function takes a publication XML:ID or a path, and sets a number of internal variables. This function is used by many commands, to provide flexibility in passing a PID or PATH to the command.
The du_setrally function reads the etc/config.properties file and sets a number of internal variables used in querying Rally's API.

appendix.title: Repository Structure
appendix.para: DPS endeavours to follow the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. However, repository submodule requirements make it necessary to place DPS in a subdirectory, somewhat breaking the standard; instead of DPS core subdirectories being at the same level as the user home directory, they are in opt/dps.
